cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: No previous knowledge of Spanish, or placement test results.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA120Y1, SPA219Y1, SPA319Y1, SPA220Y1, SPA320Y1, SPA420H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students MUST enrol in a mandatory tutorial section that corresponds to their lecture. Students who enrol in a tutorial that does not correspond with their lecture WILL be moved.

For LEC0101, enrol in TUT0101, TUT0102 or TUT0103.
For LEC0201, enrol in TUT0201, TUT0202 or TUT0203.
For LEC0301, enrol in TUT0301, TUT0302 or TUT0303.
For LEC0401, enrol in TUT0401, TUT0402 or TUT0403.
For LEC5101, enrol in TUT5101, TUT5102 or TUT5103.
For LEC5102, enrol in TUT5104, TUT5105 or TUT5106.
For LEC5201, enrol in TUT5201, TUT5202 or TUT5203.
For LEC5202, enrol in TUT5204, TUT5205 or TUT5206.

Delivery Instructions

For students enrolled in LEC5201 and corresponding tutorials (TUT5201, TUT5202 or TUT5203), it is strongly recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. All assessments will be completed in-person on campus.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the Spanish language for beginning students; overview of basic grammatical structures, development of vocabulary and oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Beginners
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Grade 12 Spanish or SPA100Y1 or LGGA30H3 or LGGA31H3 or equivalent beginner knowledge. Students are REQUIRED to complete the Spanish Language Assessment Questionnaire at https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/language-studies/language-course-assessment-questionnaires if they have any prior experience with the language.

courses.name: Class and Work in the Americas

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines economic and social inequalities in the contemporary Americas. We look at the ways in which class divisions are represented in academic studies, literature, film, and television. From Mexican maquiladoras to indigenous reservations, we consider the global poor and how recent changes in the character of work (automation, outsourcing, free trade zones) have had an impact on class divisions, especially for younger members of society. Can a renewed understanding of class and work help us to negotiate power, privilege, and inequality in this century? Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Class and Work in the Americas

courses.name: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the ways in which the foremost thinkers in the history of the Western world (Plato, Ovid, St. Augustine, Ficino, Ebreo) conceived the idea of love; how did the notions of sexuality and gender play into that idea, and how did these notions carry on – or not – into our present understanding of love, sexuality and gender. While the background readings pertain to the general Western cultural heritage, the literary texts through which we will observe particular applications of the theories of love were produced by some of the outstanding 16th and 17th century Spanish authors (for ex. Rodríguez de Montalvo; Jorge de Montemayor; Miguel de Cervantes; Tirso de Molina, María de Zayas, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz). All the readings will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

courses.name: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the ways in which the foremost thinkers in the history of the Western world (Plato, Ovid, St. Augustine, Ficino, Ebreo) conceived the idea of love; how did the notions of sexuality and gender play into that idea, and how did these notions carry on – or not – into our present understanding of love, sexuality and gender. While the background readings pertain to the general Western cultural heritage, the literary texts through which we will observe particular applications of the theories of love were produced by some of the outstanding 16th and 17th century Spanish authors (for ex. Rodríguez de Montalvo; Jorge de Montemayor; Miguel de Cervantes; Tirso de Molina, María de Zayas, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz). All the readings will be in English. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: A Brief History of Love in the Western World

courses.name: More than Nachos and Tequila: Mexican History and Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims at studying the rich history of Mexico from an interdisciplinary perspective. We will cover a wide range of issues, such as identity, modernity race, immigration, gender, sexuality, globalization, and iconic figures. The issue of identity as construed from the inside, but also from the outside and particularly from the English-speaking world (i.e. current US presidential views on the wall), will be widely examined. Course materials will range from chronicles of conquest to modern reflections and representations by historians, philosophers, filmmakers, musicians, writers and artist, among others. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: More than Nachos and Tequila: Mexican History and Culture

courses.name: Spanish for Heritage and Native Speakers I

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for heritage and native speakers with little to no knowledge of written Spanish who have basic to fluent speaking and comprehension abilities. The course provides foundations in understanding the Spanish grammatical system, opportunities to increase vocabulary and to develop writing skills and the ability to use the language across different contexts including in more formal situations. Students MUST complete the Spanish Language Assessment Questionnaire before enrolling in this course. Please visit https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/language-studies/language-course-assessment-questionnaires
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish for Heritage and Native Speakers I
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: As determined by the Spanish Language Assessment (https://www.utm.utoronto.ca/language-studies/language-course-assessment-questionnaires).
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA100Y5 or SPA219Y5 or SPA219Y1 or SPA220Y5 or SPA220Y1 or SPA319H5 or SPA320Y5

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: For native (heritage) speakers who have had exposure to spoken Spanish in an informal context (i.e., living in a Spanish-speaking country; or with a Spanish-speaking family), but little to no exposure to written Spanish. The students' ability to speak and understand Spanish may range from basic to relatively high fluency, but they cannot write and/or read Spanish. The course reviews English/Spanish spelling differences; written and spoken registers of Spanish, and basic aspects of the grammatical system. Provides students with the essential understanding of Spanish grammatical system; builds their vocabulary; and trains them to express themselves formally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Academic Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Basic to relatively high native ability to speak and understand Spanish; limited or no formal education in Spanish.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-native speakers. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Spanish

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students MUST enroll in a mandatory tutorial section according to their lecture. Students who enroll in a tutorial that does not correspond with their lecture WILL be moved. 

  • LEC0101, enroll in TUT0101 or TUT0102.
  • LEC0201, enroll in TUT0201 or TUT0202.
  • LEC5101, enroll in TUT5101 or TUT5102.
  • LEC5201, enroll in TUT5201 or TUT5202.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

cmCourseInfo.description: Intermediate Spanish for non-natives. Intensive grammar review of the structures of Spanish integrated with an introduction to reading authentic Spanish material, with practice designed to build vocabulary and to improve oral and written expression. As part of this course, students may have the option of participating in an international learning experience that will have an additional cost and application process.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Spanish

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to articulatory phonetics, Spanish sound patterns, phonetics, phonology; the basic concepts of phonetic description and transcription; the study of Spanish vowel and consonant systems, stress and intonation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Pronunciation
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA219Y1; native speakers of Spanish; SPA321H1

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A practical introduction to articulatory phonetics, Spanish sound patterns, phonetics, phonology; the basic concepts of phonetic description and transcription; the study of Spanish vowel and consonant systems, stress and intonation.
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Pronunciation
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: SPA219Y1; native speakers of Spanish; SPA321H1

courses.name: Music and Dance in Hispanic Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will explore the heritage and the modern manifestations of some Latin American, Caribbean, and Spanish musical styles and their accompanied dance forms. This course highlights the historical evolution of several prominent genres of music and dance, the place of music and dance in modern culture and their contribution in national identity and shows how European colonization and the slave trade impact on indigenous sounds and rhythms. The course is organized thematically and geographically and will be taught in English. Students who take this course for Spanish Language Citation must complete written course work in Spanish. As part of this course, students may have the option of participating in an international learning experience that will have an additional cost and application process.
cmCourseInfo.title: Music and Dance in Hispanic Culture

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to university literary studies in Spanish and information literacy. Representative selection of Spanish and Spanish American prose, poetry, and drama, with focus on critical terminology and methods of literary analysis. Required for a program degree.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literary Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Forms of cultural expression in Spain, Latin America and Spanish-speaking North America, with study of representative media, including literature, journalism, film, visual art, and the urban environment. Introduction to methods of cultural analysis. (Offered in alternate years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Cultural Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This online course examines the social, political, and cultural contexts of recent Latin American Hispanic cinema. Topics include race and indigeneity; poverty, precarity, and inequality; gender and sexuality; and memory and trauma. The representation of these themes in Latin American cinema of the 21st century has contributed to an increase in its transnational and cosmopolitan reception. Lectures in English. Students choose tutorials in Spanish or English.
cmCourseInfo.title: 21st Century Latin American Cinema

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

TUT0101 and TUT0301 are held in English for students in LAS, CIN, or otherwise interested in the topic. TUT0201 is held in Spanish for students enrolled in any SPA program.

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of Latin American cinema, analyzed within historical, social, political, and cultural contexts. Aesthetic and social forms and questions of identity will also be studied. Throughout the course, the cinema of various Spanish speaking nations, regions, and historical periods will be highlighted. The course is taught in English. Students who take this course for Spanish Language Citation must complete written course work in Spanish. [24L, 24P]
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Cinema

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or placement test.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Students MUST enroll in a mandatory tutorial section according to their lecture. Students who enroll in a tutorial that does not correspond with their lecture WILL be moved. 

  • LEC0101, enroll in TUT0101 or TUT0102
  • LEC0201, enroll in TUT0201 or TUT0202
  • LEC5101, enroll in TUT5101 or TUT5102.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: • Students enrolling in a SPA language course for the first time MUST complete the Language Course Assessment Questionnaire.

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Spanish for non-natives. Selective review of grammar with emphasis on the complex sentence; intensive practice in written and oral expression to improve proficiency. As part of this course, students may have the option of participating in an international learning experience that will have an additional cost and application process. [48L, 24P]
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Spanish

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The basic concepts and analytic tools of linguistics applied to the study of Spanish, with a focus on the Spanish phonological, morphological, and syntactic systems. Theoretical discussion and practical exercises in analytic techniques.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1; or instructor's permission

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical uses of spoken and written Spanish for business contexts, with an emphasis on culturally appropriate ways of communication in a Spanish-language work environment. This course builds on grammar and vocabulary knowledge already acquired at the intermediate level. As a part of the course, students will participate in an internship with Spanish-speaking businesses and institutions in the Toronto area. The placements are designed to deepen linguistic, cultural, and analytical skills acquired in the classroom in work-related environments, promote intercultural competency, and foster links to the community.
cmCourseInfo.title: Business Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1/ SPA220Y1/ proof of comparable Spanish level
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: SPA320Y1, SPA219Y1 or proof of comparable Spanish level

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to complete off-site assignments as part of the Community Engaged Learning component of the course for one hour per week.

cmCourseInfo.description: Practical uses of spoken and written Spanish for business contexts. This course builds on grammar and vocabulary knowledge already acquired at the intermediate level. [24L]
cmCourseInfo.title: Business Spanish

courses.name: Latin American Varieties of Spanish Through the Media

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course aims at exposing students to different varieties of Latin American Spanish. Lexical, morpho-syntactic and phonological variation will be discussed and theoretical descriptions will be illustrated by using samples from contemporary cinema and television. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Varieties of Spanish Through the Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of Catalan language through an overview of grammatical structures and exercises in proficiency skills, complemented by readings in Catalan history and society to attain interdisciplinary cultural literacy. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Catalan
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or any other 200 level Romance Language.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Pushing back against the primacy of vision, this course approaches modern Spain from the perspective of our other senses. How does the Spanish state and its concomitant nations smell, feel, taste and sound? What do these other forms of knowing tell us about cultural phenomena? In this course we will consider both primary and secondary source texts; that is, we will be touching, smelling, tasting and listening as well as analyzing the textual manifestations of sensory experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Spanish Sensorium

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Analysis of the development of Spanish Cinema within its social and political contexts. Directors studied include Buñuel, Bardem, Erice, Saura, Almodóvar and Bigas Luna. (Offered every three years).
cmCourseInfo.title: Spanish Cinema
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA120Y1 or SPA220Y1 or SPA219Y1 or Permission of the Department

courses.name: Medieval Spain Portrayed Through Visual Arts

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Through the lens of visual arts, this course will examine the evolution of complex medieval societies in the Middle Ages. We will analyse films, painting, drawing, sculpture, ceramic, images, literature, and architecture as a primary source to explain and study the past. This investigation of visual art allows us an in-depth look at medieval daily life, with a specific focus on family, violence, marriage, childhood, crimes, punishments, markets, towns, and village.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medieval Spain Portrayed Through Visual Arts

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: The end of civil and military conflicts in the last decade of the 20th century reshapes the political landscape of Central America. Through selected readings of novels and short stories from representative writers, issues of immigration, displacement, and globalization are discussed to understand these changes in the region. (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Central America Postwar Narrative

courses.name: Disability and Embodiment in Spanish American Cultures

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course approaches literary, visual, and multi-media texts of twentieth-century and contemporary Spanish America, focusing on the body as site of multiple differences, lived experience, exploitation, and creative expression. We will consider the roles of disability through cultural production and activism, particularly in the Mexican context, the histories that have shaped ongoing inequalities, and relationships between disability, gender, and race in these histories.
cmCourseInfo.title: Disability and Embodiment in Spanish American Cultures

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Linguistic analysis with the objective of improving students' command of Spanish grammar. Advanced review of traditional grammatical topics, including the verbal and pronominal systems, and Spanish copulas and embedded clauses. This course assumes familiarity with the grammatical terminology introduced in SPA320Y1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Grammar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA219Y1 or SPA320Y1, or placement test.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of Spanish morphology and syntax: syntactic categories in Spanish, the structure and interpretation of simple and complex sentences. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: The Structure of Spanish

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of linguistic variation across the Spanish-speaking world; central issues in phonological, morphological, and syntactic variation, analyzed from a geographical as well as from a social point of view. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Sociolinguistics of Spanish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: SPA322H1 or permission of the department

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Spanish Language Teaching as Reflective Practice

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: A course on specific topics in Spanish studies, designed for advanced students. Course content and instructor are established on a yearly basis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Spanish Studies

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: Literature studied as a socio-political space for the articulation of new concepts of cultural identity; examination of cultural change and aesthetic innovation in selected poetic, dramatic, and narrative texts from different national traditions (Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico). (Offered every three years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Caribbean Literatures and Identities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: At least one 300-series half-course in Spanish.

primaryOrg.name: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

cmCourseInfo.description: This course integrates a series of contemporary debates in Latin American cultural studies with analysis of its transdisciplinary history and global permutations. Key topics of investigation within these debates may include indigeneity; coloniality, transculturation, and subalternity; empire, nation, and globalism; revolution, state discourse, and the popular; gender and sexuality; and the production of race.
cmCourseInfo.title: Latin American Transculturations
